Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Experimental Macroecology: Effects of Temperature on Biodiversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The increased diversity of living organisms from the poles to the tropics is one of the most pronounced features of life on Earth. But it still lacks an explanation. One universal feature of this relationship, as seen across the land, oceans, lakes and rivers, is that hotter environments have more organisms of all kinds: animals, plants, and microbes. In this study, a big picture, or macroecological, approach will be used to study the effect of temperature on biodiversity. It will generate mathematical models for how temperature, through its effect on chemical and biological processes, affects ecological interactions and patterns of biodiversity. The models will be tested on three kinds of organisms that play key roles in forests: trees that produce leaves, small animals that eat decaying leaves and other material from plants, and microbes that consume whatever remains. Standardized field surveys along a gradient of increasing temperature from a high-elevation conifer forest in Colorado to a tropical rainforest in Panama will be combined with controlled experiments in the field and laboratory to document changes in genetic diversity, functional diversity and ecological processes.

The proposed research will predict impacts of global climate change on biodiversity and ecological processes, topics of major concern to policymakers and society. The project will also train a new generation of undergraduates, doctoral students, and postdoctoral scientists in the new multi-disciplinary, multi-investigator, collaborative research needed to address the challenging environmental problems that societies face.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the sources of Earth’s biodiversity is a key challenge in ecology. We asked how the diversity of forest life--the numbers of kinds of bacteria, fungi, animals, and plants—varied as you moved from place to place and why. We used a powerful theory, the metabolic theory of ecology, to guide our investigations. It predicts that much of what underpins ecology is related to how organisms use energy to turn food and water into individuals, a process determined importantly by how large the organism is, and the temperature of its environment.  As forest organisms vary in size by 100,000,000,000,000,000-fold and live in environments that vary in average temperature by over 30° C, we aimed to use metabolic theory to predict diversity patterns from bacteria to trees. Here are four key findings:

 

1) The answer to the question “how does diversity vary as you move from the poles to the equator?” yields a suite of answers organized by the size of the organism. When you compare an alpine forest to one from the tropics you find 100 times more tree species in the rainforest, but roughly equivalent numbers of microbes and tiny invertebrates between the two very different forest types. This is consistent with reasoning from metabolic theory that predicts how rates of evolution increase with size, effectively allowing populations of the tiniest organisms to adapt to and diversify in the variety of challenging environments out of the species rich tropics. Thus the “Latitudinal Gradient of Diversity”, often presented as monolithic law, is in fact a series of relationships predictable by one key feature: the average size of the organism.

 

2) Temperature is the second great predictor of how many species an ecosystem can support. We show this is a universal pattern, true from microbes to trees, one predicted by metabolic theory. At the same time, the precise relationship linking temperature to diversity appears to vary systematically across the major branches of the tree of life, for reasons we still do not understand.

 

3) Trees suck carbon out of the atmosphere, storing it as wood and pumping large quantities of carbon belowground via their roots. We show that the speed at which they do this is not governed like that of a “cold-blooded” ecothterm--simply conforming to the temperature of its environment. Instead, trees can subtly manipulate their own temperatures to maximize how much carbon they pull from the atmosphere.  This discovery will ultimately lead to better models allowing us to predict how increasing temperatures will change how effective trees are in scrubbing carbon from the atmosphere.

 

4) In the warm, wet tropics, temperature and moisture availability is at its peak, even as the ancient weathered soils are leached of important nutrients. We explored how adding a variety of nutrients to the soils—fertilizing with nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium and a micronutrient cocktail--shaped the diversity of soil microbes, fungi, and invertebrates.  We found the predominant pattern for plants—that adding nutrients suppresses diversity by promoting a handful of weedy species—does not hold for the soil microbes and invertebrates. The only ubiquitous decline in diversity with fertilization came from Nitrogen, not because it supports weeds but because it releases toxic aluminum trapped in the soil. Instead, adding nutrients often increased soil diversity in unexpected ways. Perhaps the most surprising result is that adding micronutrients—the Cu and Zn and Mg you find at the bottom of a multivitamin label—is the most effective way to promote the diversity of fungi and invertebrates.
